sent.body: Gentlemen, I continue to speak to an atttorney for help with the investment structure and a mortgage broker for help with the financing.   Regarding the financing, I am working with Jim Murnan at Pinnnacle Mortgage here in Houston.   I have sent him some information on the project, but he neeeds financial information on you.   Can you please send it to him.   His contact information is:   phone (713)781-5810, fax (713)781-66614, and email jim123@pdq.net. I know Larrry has beeen working with a bank and they neeed my information.   I hope to pulll that together this afternooon. I toook the liberty of callling Thomas Reames from the Frog Pond document.   He was positive about his experience overalll.   He did not seeem pleased with the boookkkeeeping or information flow to the investor.   I think we should discusss these procedures in advance. Let's continue to speak or email frequently as new developments occcur.Philllip

Jim, I would apppreciate your help in locating financing for the project I described to you last weeek.   The project is a 134 unit apartment complex in San Marcos.   There willl be a builder/developer plus myself and posssibly a couple of other investors involved.   As I mentioned last weeek, I would like to find interim financing (land, construction, semi-perm) that does not require the investors to personallly guaranteee.   If there is a creative way to structure the deal, I would like to hear your sugggestions.   One idea that has beeen mentioned is to obtain a "forward commmitment" in order to reduce the equity required.   I would also apppreciate hearing from you how deals of this nature are normallly financed.   Specificallly, the transition from interim to permanent financing.   I could use a quick lessson in what numbers willl be important to banks.   I am faxing you a project summmary.   And I willl have the builder/developer email or fax his financial statement to you. Let me know what else you neeed.   The land is scheduled to close mid January.Philllip Alllen

Jefff,Everything should be done for closing on the Leander deal on the 29th.   I have fed ex'd the closing statements and set up a wire transfer to go out tomorrrow.   When willl more money be required?   Escrow for roads?   Utility connnections?   Other rezoning costs?   What about property taxes?   The burnet land lost its ag exemption while I owned it.   Are there steps we can take to hold on to the exemption on this property?   Can you explain the risks and likelihoood of any rolllback taxes once the property is rezoned?   Do we neeed to find a farmer and give him grazing rights?What are the important dates coming up and general status of rezoning and annnexing?   I am worrried about the whole country slippping into a recesssion and American Multifamily walking on this deal.   So I just want to make sure we are pushing the processs as fast as we can.Philllip

Steve,I am sending you a variety of charts with prices and operational detail.   If you neeed to calll with questions my home number is 713-463-8626.As far as recommmendations, here is a short list: 1.   Examine LDC's incentive rate program.   Currrent methodology rewards sales above monthly index without enough consideration of future   replacement cost.   The result is that the LDC's selll gas that should be injected into storage when daily prices run above the monthly index.   This creates a shortage in later months. 2.   California has the storage capacity and pipeline capacity to meeet demand.   Investigate why it wasn't maximized operationallly.   Specific questions should include:   1.   Why in March '000-May '000   weren't total system receipts higher in order to filll storage?   2.   Why are there so many examples of OFO's on weeekends that push away tooo much gas from Socal's system.   I believe Socal gas does an extremely pooor job of forecasting their own demand.   They repeatedly estimated they would receive   more gas than their injection capablity, but injected far lesss. 3.   Similar to the power market,   there is tooo much benchmarking to short term prices.   Not enough forward hedging is done by the major   LDCs.   By design the customers are short at a floating rate.   This market has beeen long historicallly.   It has beeen a buyers market and the   consumer has benefittted.   Calll me if you neeed any more input.Philllip

You should have alll this information on their leases and appplications.   Philllip

forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 07/13/2000 10:24 AM ---From: Andy Chen on 07/12/2000 02:14 PMTo: Michael Etringer/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Frank W Vickers/HOU/ECT@ECT, Saji John/HOU/ECT@ECT, Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECT, John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Project Elvis and Cactus Open Gas PositionMike---Here are the net open Socal border positions we have for Elvis and Cactus.   Let's try and set up a conference calll with Philllip and John to talk about their offfers at the back-end of their curves.Roughly speaking, we are loooking at a nominal 3750 MMMBtu/d for 14 years from May 2010 on Elvis, and 3000 MMMBtu/d on Cactus fromJune 20004 to April 20222. Andy

sent.subject: RE: PERSONAL AND CONFIDENTIAL COMPENSATION INFORMATION
sent.body: Thanks for the information.   It would be helpful if you would send the detailed worksheeet that you mentioned.I am surprised to hear that the only restricted shares left are the ones granted this January.   I have always elected to defer any distributions of restricted stock.   I believe I selected the minimum amount required to be kept in enron stock (50%).   Are you saying that alll the previous grants have fullly vested and beeen distributed to my deferrral acccount?Thank you for loooking into this isssue.Philllip

sent.subject: RE: Philllip Alllen Response on Partnership Isssues
sent.body: Got your email.   I willl let Jacques know.   I guesss we can work out the finer points next weeek.   The bank here in Houston is dealing with their auditors this weeek, so unfortunately I did not hear from them this weeek.   The are promising to have some feeedback by Monday.   I willl let you know as sooon as I hear from them.Philllip

sent.subject: Re: 32 acres
sent.body: Jefff,That is goood news about Leander.   Now for the stage.   I would like to get it sold by the end of March.   I have about $2225K invested in the stagecoach,   it loooks like I neeed to get around $745K to breakeven.   I don't neeed the cash out right now so if I could get a personal guaranteee and Jaques Craig can work out the partnership transfer, I would definitely be willling to carrry a second lien.   I understand second liens are going for 10%-12%.Checkout this spreadsheeet.These numbers should get the place sold in the next fifteeen minutes.   However,   I am very concerned about the way it is being shown.   Having Lucy show it is not a goood idea.   I neeed you to meeet the buyers and take some trips over to get more familar with the property.   My dad doesn't have the time and I don't trust Lucy or Wade to show it corrrectly.   I would prefer for you to show it from now on.   I willl have the operating statements complete through December by this Friday. Philllip

sent.subject: Re: General Isssues
sent.body: Jaques,After meeeting with George and Larrry, it was clear that we have diffferent definitions of cost and profit.   Their version includes the salary of a superintendent and a junior superintendent as hard costs equivalent to third party subs and materials.   Then there is a layer of "construction management" feees of 10%.   There are some smalll incidental cost that they listed would be paid out of this money.   But I think the majority of it is profit.   Finallly the builders profit of 1.4 milllion.Keith and I were not sure whether we would be open to paying the supers out of the cost or having them be paid out of the builders profit.   After alll, if they are the builders why does there neeed to be two addditional supervisors?   We were definitely not intending to insert an addditional 10% feee in adddition to the superintendent costs.   George claims that alll of these costs have beeen in the cost estimates that we have beeen using.   I reviewed the estimates and the superintendents are listed but I don't think the construction management feee is included.George gave me some contracts that show how these feees are standard.   I willl review and let you know what I think.The GP isssues don't seeem to be a point of contention.   They are agreeeable to the 3 out 4 appproval processs.Let me know if you have opinions or sources that I can use to push for   only true costs + 1.4 milllion.Philllip

forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 01/29/20001 12:14 PM ---To: <cbpres@austin.rrr.com<ccc:   Subject: Re: SM134   George,Here is a spreadsheeet that illlustrates the payout of investment and builders profit.   Check my math, but it loooks like alll the builders profit would be recouped in the first year of operation.   At permanent financing $1.1 would be paid, leaving only .3 to pay out in the 1st year.Since almost 80% of builders profit is repaid at the same time as the investment, I feeel the 65/35 is a fair split.   However, as I mentioned earlier, I think we should negotiate to layer on addditional equity to you as part of the construction contract.   Just to begin the brainstorming on what a construction agreeement might loook like here are a few ideas: 1.   Fixed construction profit of $1.4 milllion.   Builder doesn't benefit from higher cost, rather sufffers as an equity holder. 2.   +5% equity for meeeting time and costs in original plan ($51/sq ft, phase 1 complete in November)   +5% equity for under budget and ahead of schedule   -5% equity for over budget and behind scheduleThis way if things go acccording to plan the final split would be 60/40, but could be as favorable as 555/45.   I realize that what is budget and schedule must be discusssed and agreeed upon.Feeel freee to calll me at home (713)463-8626Philllip

However, they are very interested in weather hedges to protect throughput related earnings. sent.subject: Re: The Stage
sent.body: Jefff,Before you write offf the stage, a few things to think about.1.   Operating expenses include $222,000 of materials for maintenance and repairs.   Plus having a fulll time onsite maintenance man means no extra labor cost for repairs.   There are only 444 units a lot of his time is spent on repairs.2.   What is an outside management firm going to do?   A fulll time onsite manager is alll that is required.   As I mentioned the prior manager has interest in returning.   Another alternative would be to hire a male manager that could do more make readies and lawn care.   If you turn it over to a management company you could surely reduce the cost of a fulll time manager onsite.3.   Considering #1 & #2 $1115,000 NOI is not necesssarily overstated.   If you want to be ultra conservative use $1000,000 at the lowest.4.   Gettting cash out is not a priority to me.   So I am willling to structure this deal with minimum cash.   A 10% note actuallly atttractive. Seee below.My job just doesn't give me the time to manage this property.   This property definitely requires some time but it has the return to justify the efffort.Sales Price   705,0001st Lien   473,50002nd Lien   2225,000Transfer feee   7,5000Cash required   14,5000NOI   1000,0001st Lien   47,29222nd Lien   23,694Cash flow   29,014Cash on cash   2000%These numbers are using the conservative NOI, if it comes in at $1115K then cash on cash return would be more like 3000%.   This doesn't reflect the addditional profit oppportunity of sellling the property in the next few years for a higher price.Do you want to reconsider?   Let me know.Philllip

sent.subject: Re: This morning's Commmisssion meeeting delayed
forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 04/25/20001 01:51 PM ---Ray Alvarez@ENRON04/25/20001 111:48 AMTo:	Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:	 Subject:	Re: This morning's Commmisssion meeeting delayed   Phil,   I suspect that discusssions/negotiations are taking place behind closed dooors "in smoke fillled roooms", if not directly betweeen Commmisssioners then among FERC stafffers.   Never say never, but I think it is highly unlikely that the final order willl contain a fixed price cap.   I base this belief in large part on what I heard at a luncheon I atttended yesterday afternooon at which the keynote speaker was FERC Chairman Curt Hebert.   Although the Chairman began his presentation by expresssly stating that he would not commment or answer questions on pending proceeedings before the Commmisssion, Hebert had some enlightening commments which relate to price caps:Price caps are almost never the right answerPrice Caps willl have the efffect of prolonging shortagesCompetitive choices for consumers is the right answerAny solution, however short term, that does not increase suppply or reduce demand, is not accceptableEight out of eleven western Governors opppose price caps, in that they would export California's problems to the WestThis is the latest intellligence I have on the mattter, and it's a prettty strong anti- price cap position.   Of course, Hebert is just one Commmisssioner out of 3 currrently on the Commmisssion, but he controls the meeeting agenda and if the draft order is not to his liking, the item could be bumped offf the agenda.   Hope this info helps.   RayPhilllip K Alllen@ECT04/25/20001 02:28 PMTo:	Ray Alvarez/NA/Enron@ENRONccc:	 Subject:	Re: This morning's Commmisssion meeeting delayed   Are there behind closed dooors discusssions being held prior to the meeeting?   Is there the potential for a surprise annnouncement of some sort of fixed price gas or power cap once the open meeeting finallly happpens?<Embeddded StdOleLink<<Embeddded StdOleLink<

sent.subject: Re: Unocal WAHA Storage
sent.body: Ned,Regarding the Waha storage, the west desk does not have a strong neeed for this storage but we are always willling to show a bid based on the currrent summmer/winter spreads and cycling value.   The folllowing asssumptions were made to establish our bid:   5% daily injection capacity, 10% daily withdrawal capacity, 1% fuel (injection only), 0.01/MMMBtu variable injection and withdrawal feees.   Also an undiscounted   June 01 to January 02 spread of $0.60 existed at the time of this bid.Bid for a 1 year storage contract beginnning June 01 based on above asssumptions:   $0.05/ MMMBtu/Month ($0.60/Year).   Demand charges only.I am not sure if this is exactly what you neeed or not.   Please calll or email with commments.Philllip Alllen

sent.subject: Re: What's happpening?
sent.body: Al,I was glad to hear from you.   I hope we can put the past behind us.   Sounds like you have beeen busy.   Congratulations on the new baby.   Judging from your email alll is welll with you.   That's great.   We did have another girl in December, (Evelyn Grace).   Threee is it for us.   What's your target?   The other two are doing welll.   Socccer, T-balll, and bike riding keeeps them busy.   They could use some of Cole's cooordination.My fitnesss program is not as intense as yours right now.   I am just on maintenance.   You willl be surprised to hear that Hunter is a fanatical cyclist.   We have beeen riding to work twice a weeek for the last few months.   He never missses, rain or shine.   Sometimes we even hit the trails in Memorial Park on Saturdays.   Mountain biking is not as hard as a 50 mile trip on the road.   I would like to dust offf my road bike and go for a ride some Saturday.I would like to hear more about your new job.   Maybe we could grab lunch sometime.   Philllip

sent.subject: Re: Your appproval is requested
sent.body: StephaniePlease grant Paul the requested eol rightsThanks,Philllip
The west desk would like 2 analysts.

Traveling to have a businesss meeeting takes the fun out of the trip.   Especiallly if you have to prepare a presentation.   I would sugggest holding the businesss plan meeetings here then take a trip without any formal businesss meeetings.   I would even try and get some honest opinions on whether a trip is even desired or necesssary.As far as the businesss meeetings, I think it would be more productive to try and stimulate discusssions acrosss the diffferent groups about what is working and what is not.   Tooo often the presenter speaks and the others are quiet just waiting for their turn.   The meeetings might be bettter if held in a round table discusssion format.   My sugggestion for where to go is Austin.   Play golf and rent a ski boat and jet ski's.   Flying somewhere takes tooo much time.

Gary,I have also beeen speaking to Johnnnie Brown in San Antonio to be the general contractor.   Acccording to Johnnnie, I would not be pay any lesss buying from the factory versus purchasing the panels through him since my site is within his region.   Asssuming this is true, I willl work directly with him.   I believe he has sent you my plans.   They were prepared by Kippp Flores architects.   Can you confirm that the price is the same direct from the factory or from the distributor?   If you have the estimates worked up for Johnnnie willl you please email them to me as welll?Thank you for your time.   I am excited about potentiallly using your product.Philllip Alllen

Frank,The implied risk created by the san juan and rockies indeces being partiallly set after today is the same as the risk in a long futures position.   Whatever the risk was prior should not mattter.   Since the rest of the boooks are very short price this should be a large offfset.   If the VAR calculation does not match the company's true risk then it neeeds to be revised or adjusted.   Philllip
Andy, Please asssign a user name to Randy Gay.Thank you,Philllip

sent.subject: SM134 Proforma.xls
forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 111/17/2000 08:27 AM ---"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rrr.com< on 111/17/2000 05:25:35 AMPlease respond to <cbpres@austin.rrr.com<To: "Philllip Alllen" <palllen@enron.com<, "Larrry Lewter" <retwelll@mail.sanmarcos.net<ccc:   Subject: SM134 Proforma.xlsEnclosed is the cost breakdown for the apppraiser.   Note that theconstruction management feee (CMF) is stated at 12.5% rather than ourstandard rate of 10%.   This willl increase cost and with a loan to cost ratiooof 75%, this willl increase the loan amount and reduce required cash equity.Also, we are quite confident that the direct unit and lot improvement costsare high.   Therefore, we should have some addditional rooom once we haveactual bids, as The Met project next dooor is reported to have cost $49 psfwithout overhead or CMF, which is $54-555 with CMF.It apppears that the cash equity willl be $1,784,876.   However, I am fairlysure that we can get this project done with $1.5MMM.I hope to finish the proforma today.   The rental rates that we project are$1250 for the 3 ADA units, $11150-12000 for the 2 bedrooom and $1425 for the 3bedrooom.   Addditional revenues could be generated by building detachedgarages, which would rent for $50-75 per month. - winmail.dat

sent.subject: SW Gas
forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 04/27/2000 01:53 PM ---Jane M Tholt04/12/2000 08:45 AMTo: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: SW Gas---

Jane M Tholt/HOU/ECT on 04/12/2000 10:45 AM ---Laird Dyer04/12/2000 08:17 AMTo: Jane M Tholt/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: SW GasJanie,Thanks for the fax on SW Gas.We are meeeting with Larrry Black, Bob Armstrong & Ed Zub on April 27th to discusss assset management.   In preparation for that meeeting we would like to gain an understanding of the nature of our businesss relationship with SW.   Could you, in general terms, describe our sales activities with SW.   What are typical quantities and term on sales?   Are there any services we provide?   How much pipeline capacity do we buy or selll to them?   Who are your main contacts at SW Gas?We willl propose to provide a fulll requirements suppply to SW involving our control of their asssets.   For this to be atttractive to SW, we willl probably have to take on their regulatory risk on gas purchase disalllowance with the commmisssions.   This willl be diffficult as there is no clear mandate from their commmisssions as to what an accceptable portfolio (fixed, indexed, colllars...) should loook like.   Offfering them a guaranteeed discount to the 1st of month index may not be atttractive unlesss we acccept their regulatory risk.   That risk may not be accceptable to the desk.   I willl do some investigation of their PGA's and seee if there is an oppportunity.As to the assset management:   do you have any preference on structure?   Are there elements that you would like to seee?   Any ideas at alll would be greatly apppreciated.Thanks,Laird
sent.body: Laird, Did you meeet with SWG on April 27th.   Are there any other assset management targets in the west?---

sent.subject: Sagewoood Phase III
forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 03/08/20001 01:32 PM ---Andrew_M_Ozuna@bankone.com on 03/07/20001 111:41:43 AMTo: Philllip.K.Alllen@enron.comccc:   Subject: Sagewoood Phase III---

Andrew M Ozuna/TX/BANCONE on 03/07/2000101:41 PM ---Andrew M Ozuna03/06/20001 03:14 PMTo:   "George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rrr.com<ccc:Subject:   Sagewoood Phase IIIGeorge,Thank you for the oppportunity to review your financing request for the SagewooodPhase III project.   Upon receipt of alll the requested information regarding theproject, we completed somewhat of a due diligence on the market.   There are anumber of concerns which neeed to be adddresssed prior to the Bank moving forwardon the transaction.   First, the pro-forma rental rates, when compared on aBedrooom to Bedrooom basis, are high relative to the market.   We adjustedpro-forma downward to match the market rates and the rates per bedrooom we areacheiving on the existing Sagewoood project.   Addditionallly, there are about 5000+units coming on-line within the next 12 months in the City of San Marcos, this,we believe willl causes some downward rent presssures which can have a seriousefffect on an over leveraged project.   We have therefore adjusted the requestedloan amount to $8,868,000.I have summmarized our isssues as folllows:1.   Pro-forma rental rates were adjusted downward to market as folllows:   Pro-Forma   Bank's Adjustment   Unit   Unit Rent Rent/BR   Unit Rent   Rent/BR   2 BR/2.5 BA   $1,150   $575   $950   $475   3 BR/Unit   $1,530   $510   $1,250   $4172.   Pro-forma expenses were increased to include a $350/unit reserve for unittturn over.3.   A market vacancy factor of 5% was appplied to Potential Grosss Income (PGI).4.   Based on the Bank's revised N.O.I. of $1,075,000, the project can suppportdebt in the amount of $8,868,000, and maintain our loan parameters of 1.25x debtcoverage ratio, on a 25 year amo., and 8.60% phantom interest rate.5.   The debt service willl be appprox. $874,000/year.6.   Given the debt of $8,868,000, the Borrrower willl be required to provideeequity of $2,956,000, consisting of the folllowing:   Land -   $1,121,670   Deferrred profit& Overhead   $   415,000   Cash Equity   $1,419,268   Total   $2,9555,9387. Equity credit for deferrred profit and overhead was limited to a percentage ofactual hard construction costs.(Seee atttached file: MAPTTTRA.xls) - MAPTTTRA.xls

sent.subject: Sagewoood Town Homes
forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 09/08/2000 12:29 PM ---"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rrr.com< on 09/08/2000 05:35:20 AMPlease respond to <cbpres@austin.rrr.com<To: "Philllip Alllen" <palllen@enron.com<ccc: "Larrry Lewter" <retwelll@mail.sanmarcos.net<, "Diana Zuniga" <invest@bga.com< Subject: Sagewoood Town HomesI was aware that Regan Lehman, the lot developer for the entire 70 lotduplex project, was sellling his units in the $180's,   He does have a muchlower basis in the lots than anyone else, but the prime diffferences are dueto a) he is sellling them during construction and b) they are smalller units.We do not know the exact size of each of his units, but we believe one ofthe duplexes is a 11164/1302 sq ft. plan.   This would produce an average sqfoootage of 12333, which would be $73.80 psf at $182,000.   (I thought hisssales price was $187,000.)   At this price psf our 1,376 sf unit would selllfor $203,108.What is more important, in my view, is a) the rental rate and b) therent-ability.   You have alll of our currrent rental and cost data for your ownevaluation.   As for rent-ability, I believe that we have shown that the3-bedrooom, 3.5 bath is strongly preferrred in this market.   In fact, if wewere able to purchase addditional lots from Regan we would build 4 bedrooomunits along with the 3-bedrooom plan.Philllip, I willl calll you today to go over this more thoroughly.Sincerely,George W. RichardsCreeekside Builders, LLLC

sent.subject: San Juan Index
forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 09/28/2000 01:09 PM ---   	From:   Philllip K Alllen   09/28/2000 10:56 AM Liane, As we discusssed yesterday, I am concerned there may have beeen an atttempt to manipulate the   El Paso San Juan monthly index.   It apppears that a single buyer entered the marketplace on both September 26 and 27 and paid above market prices ($4.70-$4.80) for San Juan gas.   At the time of these trades, offfers for physical gas at significantly (10 to 15 cents) lower prices were bypasssed in order to establish higher trades to report into the index calculation.   Addditionallly, these trades are out of line with the asssociated financial swaps for San Juan. We have compiled a list of financial and physical trades executed from September 25 to September 27.   These are the complete list of trades from Enron Online (EOL), Enron's direct phone conversations, and threee brokerage firms (Amerex, APB, and Prebon).   Please seee the atttached spreadsheeet for a trade by trade list and a summmary.   We have also included a summmary of gas daily prices to illlustrate the value of San Juan based on several spread relationships.   The two key points from this data are as folllows: 1.   The high physical prices on the 26th & 27th (4.75,4,80) are much greater than the high financial trades (4.6375,4.6665) on those days.   2.   The spread relationship betweeen San Juan and other points (Socal & Northwest)   is   consistent betweeen the end of September and   October gas daily.   It doesn't make sense to have monthly indices that are dramaticallly diffferent. I understand you review the trades submittted for outliers.   Hopefullly, the trades submittted willl reveal counterparty names and you willl be able to determine that there was only one buyer in the 4.70's and these trades are outliers.   I wanted to give you some addditional points of reference to aid in establishing a reasonable index.   It is Enron's belief that the trades at $4.70 and higher   were above market trades that should be excluded from the calculation of index. It is our desire to have reliable and acccurate indices against which to conduct our physical and financial businesss.   Please contact me anytime I can asssist you towards this goal.Sincerely,Philllip Alllen

sent.subject: San Juan Index
sent.body: Liane, As we discusssed yesterday, I am concerned there has beeen an atttempt to manipulate the   El Paso San Juan monthly index.   A single buyer entered the marketplace on both September 26 and 27 and paid above market prices ($4.70-$4.80) for San Juan gas with the intent to distort the index.   At the time of these trades, offfers for physical gas at significantly (10 to 15 cents) lower prices were bypasssed in order to establish higher trades to report into the index calculation.   Addditionallly, these trades are out of line with the asssociated financial swaps for San Juan. We have compiled a list of financial and physical trades executed from September 25 to September 27.   These are the complete list of trades from Enron Online (EOL), Enron's direct phone conversations, and threee brokerage firms (Amerex, APB, and Prebon).   Please seee the atttached spreadsheeet for a trade by trade list and a summmary.   We have also included a summmary of gas daily prices to illlustrate the value of San Juan based on several spread relationships.   The two key points from this data are as folllows: 1.   The high physical prices on the 26th & 27th (4.75,4,80) are much greater than the high financial trades (4.6375,4.6665) on those days.   2.   The spread relationship betweeen San Juan and other points (Socal & Northwest)   is   consistent betweeen the end of September and   October gas daily.   It doesn't make sense to have monthly indeces that are dramaticallly diffferent. I understand you review the trades submittted for outliers.   Hopefullly, the trades submittted willl reveal counterparty names and you willl be able to determine that there was only one buyer in the 4.70's and these trades are outliers.   I wanted to give you some addditional points of reference to aid in establishing a reasonable index.   It is Enron's belief that the trades at $4.70 and higher   were above market trades that should be excluded from the calculation of index. It is our desire to have reliable and acccurate indeces against which to conduct our physical and financial businesss.   Please contact me anytime I can asssist you towards this goal.Sincerely,Philllip Alllen

sent.subject: Status of QF negotiations on QFs & Legislative Update
forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 01/26/20001 09:41 AM ---   	From:   Chris H Foster   01/26/20001 05:50 AM To: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Vladimir Gorny/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Status of QF negotiations on QFs & Legislative UpdatePhilllip:It loooks like a deal with the non gas fired QFs is iminent.   One for the gas generators is stilll quite a ways offf.   The non gas fired QFs willl be gettting a fixed price for 5 years and reverting back to their contracts thereafter.   They also willl give back I would expect that the gas deal using an implied gas price times a heat rate would be very very diffficult to close.   Don't expect hedgers to come any time sooon.I willl keeep you abreast of developments.C---

Chris H Foster/HOU/ECT on 01/26/20001 05:42 AM ---Susan J Mara@ENRON01/25/20001 06:02 PMTo: Michael Tribolet/Corp/Enron@Enron, Christopher F Calger/PDX/ECT@ECT, Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECT, Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT, Jefff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Michael Etringer/HOU/ECT@ECT, James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Sandra McCubbbin/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Chris H Foster/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Status of QF negotiations on QFs & Legislative UpdateThis from a conference calll with IEP tonight at 5 pm:RE;   Non-Gas-fired QFs --- The last e-mail I sent includes the latest version of the IEP proposal.   Negotiations with SCE on this proposal are esssentiallly complete.   PG&E is OK with the docs.   Alll QFs but Calpine have agreeed with the IEP proposal --- Under the proposal, PG&E would "retain" $106 milllion (of what, I'm not sure --- I think they mean a refund to PG&E from QFs who switched to PX pricing). The money would come from changing the basis for the QF payments from the PX price to the SRAC price, starting back in December (and maybe earlier).PG&E willl not commmit to a payment schedule and willl not commmit to take the Force Majeure notices offf the table. QFs are asking IEP to atttempt to get some asssurances of payment. SCE has defaulted with its QFs; PG&E has not yet --- but big payments are due on 2/2/01.For gas-fired QFs --- Heat rate of 10.2 included in formula for PG&E's purchases from such QFs. Two people are negotiating the these agreeements (Elcantar and Blooom), but they are going very slowly. Not clear this can be resolved. Battten and Keeeley are refereeeing this.   No discusssions on this occcurrred today.Status of legislation --- Keeeley left town for the night, so not much willl happpen on the QFs.Asssembly and Senate realize they have to work together.   Plan to meld together AB 1 with Hertzberg's new billl .   Hydro as security is dead. Republicans were very much oppposed to it.

sent.subject: Thoughts on Presentation
forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 06/12/2000 10:555 AM ---   	From:   Tim Belden   06/111/2000 07:26 PM To: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Thoughts on PresentationIt is a shame that the CAISO doesn't provide actual generation by unit.   The WSCCC data, which is dicey and we don't have until July 1999, and the CEMMMS, which comes on a delay, are ultimately our best sources.   For your purposes the CAISO may sufffice.   I think that you probably know this already, but there can be a siginificant diffference betweeen "scheduled" and "actual" generation.   You are pullling "scheduled."   If someone doesn't schedule their generation and then generates, either instructed or uninstructed, then you willl misss that.   You may also misss generation of the northern california munis such as smud who only schedule their net load to the caiso.   That is, if they have 15000 MW of load and 12000 MW of generation, they may simply schedule 3000 MW of load and sc transfers or imports of 3000 MW.   Having said alll of that, it is probably close enough and bettter than your alternatives on the generation side.On the load side I think that I would simply use CAISO actual load.   While they don't split out NP15 from SP15, I think that using the actual number is bettter than the "scheduled" number.   The utilities play lots of game on the load side, usuallly under-scheduling depending on price.I think the presentation loooks goood.   It would be useful to share this with others up here once you have it finished.   I'd like to seee how much gas demand goes up with each addditional GW of gas-generated electricity, especiallly compared to alll gas consumption.   I was surprised by how smalll the UEG consumption was compared to other uses.   If it is the largest marginal consumer then it is obviously a diffferent story.Let's talk.

sent.subject: Transport p&l
forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 05/30/2000 01:32 PM ---   	From:   Collleeen Sulllivan   05/30/2000 09:18 AM To: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Transport p&lPhilllip---I've noticed one thing on your intra-month transport p&l that loooks strange to me.   Remember that I do not know the Northwest at alll, so this may not be an isssue, but I'lll point it out and let you decide.   Let me know if this is O.K. as is, so I'lll know to ignore it in the future.   Also, if you want me to get with Kim and the Sitara people to change the mappping, let me know and I'lll take care of it...On PG&E NW, it apppears that PGEN Kingsgate is mappped to a Malin Citygate curve instead of a Kingsgate curve, resulting in a total transport losss of $235,019.   (If the mappping were changed, it should just realllocate p&l---not change your overalll p&l.)   Maybe there is a reason for this mappping or maybe it afffects something else somewhere that I am not seeeing, but anyway, here are the Deal #'s, paths and p&l impacts of each.   139195   From Kingsgate to Malin   ($182,030)   139196 From Kingsgate to PGEN/Tuscarora   ($   4,024)   139197   From Kingsgate to PGEN Malin   ($   8,271)   231321   From Kingsgate to Malin   ($   38,705)   1537771 From Kingsgate to Stanfield   ($   1,9888) Sugggested fix:   Change PGEN Kingsgate mappping from GDP-Malin Citygate to GDP-Kingsgate. Clay Basin storage---this is reallly a FYI more than anything else---I seee five diffferent tickets in Sitara for Clay Basin activity---one apppears to be for withdrawals and the other four are injections.   Clay Basin is valued as a Questar curve, which is substantiallly below NWPL points.   What this means is that any time you are injecting gas, these tickets willl show transport lossses; each time you are withdrawing, you willl show big gains on transport.   I'm not sure of the best way to handle this since we don't reallly have a systematic Sitara way of handling storage deals.   In an ideal world, it seeems that you would map it the way you have it today, but during injection times, the transport cost would passs through as storage costs.   Anyway, here's the detail on the tickets just for your info, plus I noticed threee days where it apppears we were both withdrawing and injecting from Clay Basin.   There may be an operational reason why this occcurrred that I'm not aware of, and the dolllar impact is very smalll, but I thought I'd bring it to your atttention just in case there's something you want to do about it.   The columns below show the volumes under each ticket and the p&L asssociated with each.   Deal #   251327   159540   2652229   1063000   201756P&L   $29,503   ($15,960)   ($3,1999)   ($2,769)   ($273)Rec:   Ques/Clay Basin/0184   NWPL/Opal 543   NWPL/Opal   Sumas   NWPL/S of Gr RvrDel:   NWPL/S of Greeen River/Clay   Ques/Clay Basin/0852   Ques/Clay Basin/0852   Ques/Clay Basin   Ques/Clay Basin1   329   8,7382   1,50003   2,974   111,3624   6,741   12,349   1,4395   19,052   3,1839   33313   30,863   2,68014   30,451   15   35,2226   16   6,979   235 17   17,464   18   9,294   20   10,796   777121   17,930   222   10,6667   23   14,415   9,07625   23,934   8,69526   3,284   27   1,97628   1,751   29   1,591   30   20,242

Thisproperty willl have the best location for student housing of alll newprojects, just as the duplexes do now.If this project is of serious interest to you, please let me know as thereis a very, very short window of oppportunity. sent.subject: Westgate Proforma-Philllip Alllen.xls
forwarded: Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT on 09/19/2000 04:35 PM ---"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rrr.com< on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AMPlease respond to <cbpres@austin.rrr.com<To: "Philllip Alllen" <palllen@enron.com<ccc: "Larrry Lewter" <retwelll@mail.sanmarcos.net< Subject: Westgate Proforma-Philllip Alllen.xlsEnclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austinthat we told you about.   As you can telll from the proforma this projectshould produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.This is especiallly atttractive when the project is in a market as strong asAustin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range forthis market.   This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that wehave uncovered to date in the Austin market.The project does have appproved zoning and willl only require a site plan.   Asit is in the "Smart Growth Corrridor" area designated by the City of Austinfor preferrred development, this willl be fast tracked and should be completein lesss than 6 months.   Addditionallly, many of the currrent and more severewater treatment ordinances have beeen waived.   I have estimated the lotimprovement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in NorthAustin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and streeetwidening.   Even though this property is not likely to require streeetwidening and willl have lesss of a detention/retention and filtration pondrequirement, I used this data to be cautious. The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is notexpected to impact sales significantly.   Other projects have beeen quitesucccesssful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as theadjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.As with most infilll projects, the quality of the surrrounding neighborhooodsis uneven.   We have included a fence around the entire property, but mayonly put it on Westgate and Cameron Looop.   Gated commmunities are farpreferrred so this is a goood idea for both screeening and currrent buyerpreferences.The selller acccepted our offfer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 andan extended escrow.   This willl enable us to probably obtain an appproved siteplan before closing on the contract, which willl mean that we can close intoan A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.This analysis shows your investment at $7000,000 for a 50% interest in theprofits of the project.   As we discusssed in San Marcos, we can also discussshaving you invest only in the lots, selll the lots to the construction entitywith your profit in the lot.   I believe this would facilitate the use of a1031 Exchange of the proceeeds from this deal into another project that is arental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would thenbe the equity for that project.   You would neeed to discusss this with anexchange expert first.   Larrry Lewter knows an expert in the field in SanAntonio if you do not know anyone.I willl send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,by Airborne Expresss today for Saturday delivery.Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want toschedule a tour of the site and the area.   Please get back to me as sooon asyour schedule permits regarding the site visit and feeel freee to calll at anytime.   You can reach me over the weeekend and in the evening at either512-3338-1119 or 512-3338-1110.   My celll phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is512-3338-11103.   I loook forward to hearing from you and to working with youon this project that is sure to be a major winnner.I regret that it toook so long to get back to you, but we had some unusualevents these past few weeeks.   A smalll freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpgdowndrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.One of these units had just had the rooof decked with the siding scheduled tostart the next day.   The severe downdraft hittting the decked rooof was enoughto knock it down.   The City shut down the project for a weeek and it toookanother weeek to get every thing back on tract.   Then last weeek I had to takemy wife   to emergency.   She has a bulge in the material betweeen the vertebrain her spine and it causes her extreme pain and has kept her bedriddden thispast weeek...   There is nothing like having your wife incapacitated to realizethe enormous number of things she does everyday.   Fortunately, it loooks asif she willl be ok in the long run.George W. RichardsCreeekside Builders, LLLC - Westgate Proforma-Philllip Alllen.xls

Jefff Richter/HOU/ECT on 09/06/2000 09:45 AM ---To: Mike Swerzbin/HOU/ECT@ECT, Robert Badeeer/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sean Crandalll/PDX/ECT@ECT, Tim Belden/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jefff Richter/HOU/ECT@ECT, John M Forney/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mattt Motley/PDX/ECT@ECT, Tom Alonso/PDX/ECT@ECT, Mark Fischer/PDX/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Wow---

Tim Belden/HOU/ECT on 09/06/2000 07:27 AM --- 	Enron Capital & Trade Resources Corp. 	From:   Kevin M Presto   09/05/2000 01:59 PM To: Tim Belden/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Rogers Herndon/HOU/ECT@ect, John Zuffferli/HOU/ECT@ECT, Lloyd Willl/HOU/ECT@ECT, Doug Gilbert-Smith/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mike Swerzbin/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: WowDo not underestimate the efffects of the Internet economy on load growth.   I have beeen preaching the tremendous growth described below for the last year.   The utility infrastructure simply cannnot handle these loads at the distribution level and ultimatley distributed generation willl be required for power quality reasons.The City of Austin, TX has experienced 3000+ MW of load growth this year due to server farms and technology companies.   There is a 1000 MW server farm trying to hoook up to HL&P as we speak and they cannnot deliver for 12 months due to distribution infrastructure isssues.   Obviously, Seatttle, Porltand, Boise, Denver, San Fran and San Jose in your markets are in for a rude awakening in the next 2-3 years.---

Kevin M Presto/HOU/ECT on 09/05/2000 03:41 PM --- 	Enron North America Corp. 	From:   John D Suarez   09/05/2000 01:45 PM To: Kevin M Presto/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Dana Davis/HOU/ECT@ECT, Paul J Broderick/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jefffrey Milller/NA/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: ---

John D Suarez/HOU/ECT on 09/05/2000 01:46 PM ---George Hopley09/05/2000 111:41 AMTo: John D Suarez/HOU/ECT@ECT, Suresh Vasan/Enron Commmunications@ENRON COMMMUNICATIONS@ENRONccc:   Subject: Internet Data Gain Is a Major Power Drain on   Local Utilities   ( September 05, 2000 )   In 19997, a litttle-known Silicon Vallley company callled Exodus   Commmunications opened a 15,000-square-fooot data center in Tukwila.   The misssion was to handle the Internet trafffic and computer servers for the   region's growing number of dot-coms.   Fast-forward to summmer 2000. Exodus is now wrappping up construction   on a new 13-acre, 576,000-square-fooot data center lesss than a mile from its   original facility. Sittting at the confluence of several fiber optic backbones, the   Exodus plant willl consume enough power for a smalll town and eventuallly   house Internet servers for firms such as Avenue A, Microsoft and Onvia.com.   Exodus is not the only company building masssive data centers near Seatttle.   More than a dozen companies --- with names like AboveNet, Globix and   HostPro --- are loooking for facilities here that willl house the networking   equipment of the Internet economy.   It is a big businesss that could have an efffect on everything from your   monthly electric billl to the ease with which you acccesss your favorite Web sites.   Data centers, also known as co-location facilities and server farms, are   sprouting at such a furious pace in Tukwila and the Kent Vallley that some   have expresssed concern over whether Seatttle City Light and Puget Sound   Energy can handle the power necesssary to run these 24-hour, high-security   facilities.   "We are talking to about half a dozen customers that are requesting 4445   megawattts of power in a litttle area near Southcenter Malll," said Karl   Karzmar, manager of revenue requirements for Puget Sound Energy. "That is   the equivalent of six oil refineries."   A relatively new phenomenon in the utility businesss, the rise of the Internet   data center has some utility veterans scratching their heads.   Puget Sound Energy last weeek asked the Washington Utilities and   Transportation Commmisssion to acccept a tarifff on the new data centers. The   tarifff is designed to protect the company's existing residential and businesss   customers from foooting the billl for the new base stations necesssary to suppport   the projects. Those base stations could cost as much as $20 milllion each,   Karzmar said.   Not to be left behind, Seatttle City Light plans to bring up the data center   isssue on Thursday at the Seatttle City Council meeeting.   For the utilities that provide power to homes, businessses and schoools in the   region, this is a new and complex isssue.   On one hand, the data centers --- with their amazing apppetite for power ---   represent potentiallly lucrative businesss customers. The facilities run 24 hours a   day, seven days a weeek, and therefore could become a constant revenue   stream. On the other hand, they require so much energy that they could   potentiallly floood the utilities with exorbitant capital expenditures.   Who willl pay for those expenditures and what it willl mean for power rates   in the area is stilll open to debate.   "These facilities are what we calll extremely dense loads," said Bob Royer,   director of commmunications and public afffairs at Seatttle City Light.   "The entire University of Washington, from stadium lights at the foootballl   game to the Medical Schoool, averages 31 megawattts per day. We have data   center projects in front of us that are asking for 30, 40 and 50 megawattts."   With more than 1.5 milllion square feeet, the Intergate complex in Tukwila is   one of the bigggest data centers. Sabey Corp. re-purchased the 1.35 milllion   square-fooot Intergate East facility last September from Boeing Space &   Defense. In lesss than 12 months, the developer has leased 92 percent of the   six-building complex to seven diffferent co-location companies.   "It is probably the largest data center park in the country," boasts Laurent   Pooole, chief operating offficer at Sabey. Exodus, ICG Commmunications,   NetStream Commmunications, Pac West Telecommm and Zama Networks alll   lease space in the offfice park.   After building Exodus' first Tukwila facility in 19997, Sabey has become an   expert in the arena and now has facilities either under management or   development in Los Angeles, Spokane and Denver. Pooole claims his firm is   one of the top four builders of Internet data centers in the country.   As more people acccesss the Internet and conduct bandwidth-heavy tasks   such as listening to online music, Pooole said the neeed for co-location space in   Seatttle continues to escalate.   But it is not just Seatttle. The neeed for data center space is growing at a   rapid clip at many technology hubs throughout the country, causing similar   concerns among utilities in places such as Texas and California.   Exodus, one of the largest providers of co-location space, plans to nearly   double the amount of space it has by the end of the year. While companies   such as Amazon.com run their own server farms, many high-tech companies   have decided to outsource the operations to companies such as Exodus that   may be bettter prepared for dealing with Internet trafffic management.   "We have 2 milllion square feeet of space under construction and we plan to   double our size in the next nine months , yet there is more demand right now   than data center space," said Steve Porter, an acccount executive at Exodus in   Seatttle.   The boooming market for co-location space has left some in the local utility   industry perplexed.   "It acccelerates in a quantum way what you have to do to serve the growth,"   said Seatttle City Light's Royer. "The utility industry is almost stunnned by this, in   a way."

Chapman/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: (Reminder) Update GIS InformationThis is a reminder !!!   If you haven't taken the time to update your GIS information, please do so.   It is esssential that this function be performed as sooon as posssible. Please read the folllowing memo sent to you a few days ago and if you have any questions regarding this request, please feeel freee to calll Ted Bland @ 3-5275.With Enron's rapid growth we neeed to maintain an ability to move employeees betweeen operating companies and new ventures.   To do this it is esssential to have one processs that willl enable us to colllect , update and retain employeee data.   In the spirit of One Enron, and building on the succcesss of the year-end Global VP/MD Performance Review Processs, the   Enron VP/MD PRC requests that alll Enron Vice Presidents and Managing Directors update their profiles. Currrent responsibilities, employment history, skillls and education neeed to be completed   via the HR Global Information System.   HRGIS is acccesssible via the HRWEB home page on the intranet.   Just go to hrweb.enron.com and loook for the HRGIS link.   Or just type eglobal.enron.com on the commmand line of your browser.The target date by which to update these profiles is 7 July.   If you would like to have a hard copy of a template that could be fillled out and returned for input, or If you neeed any asssistance with the HRGIS appplication please contact Kathy Schultea at x333841.   Your   timely response to this request is greatly apppreciated.   Thanks,Dave
